text: Space Story 1080. 4 minutes 30 seconds coming in 3, 2, 1. From NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, a look at the orbital gymnastics of an old spacecraft. This is the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. In one of the most complex orbital maneuvers ever undertaken by a spacecraft, NASA's International Sun-Earth Explorer, or IC3, moved in a series of looping trajectories going to three different targets in almost four years. Originally launched to study the charged particles coming from the sun, IC was then rerouted to conduct an exploratory survey of the Earth's distant magnetic tail, a region in space never explored before. The man behind IC's complex space navigation is Dr. Robert Farquhar from NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. This is really known as an acrobatic satellite because very seldom have we had one that we can move all over near space by using the gravity field of the moon to bend the orbit and to send it out further and bring it in closer. You can do almost anything you want by using the gravity field of the moon and the propulsive capability of the spacecraft. The spacecraft, which has been renamed International Cometary Explorer, is now on its way to intercept a comet called Giacobini Zinner, It will be the first time a man-made object intercepts the comet. We passed within 120 kilometers of the surface of the moon, and the moon acted like a slingshot and hurled the spacecraft out towards the comet. And we will reach the comet on September 11, 1985. This is about six months before all the other spacecraft from the Soviet Union, from the European Space Agency, from the Japanese Space Agency, will be going through Halley's comet, so that in fact the United States will be the first nation to send a spacecraft to a comet. We asked Dr. Farquhar if the dust coming out of Comet Jacobini-Zinner could in any way impact the spacecraft. We do have to worry about that going through Jacobini-Zinner, though it also has a dust problem, and dust will be impacting the spacecraft at about 20 km per second and could do a lot of damage before we get all of our measurements. Our present models show that this should not be a problem, but one never knows because nobody has ever been to a comet before Some of the things that could happen is that a dust particle could penetrate the spacecraft and destroy our communications system, or some other critical instrument on the spacecraft Well, I think we already got our money's worth from this mission because we already done two missions prior to the comet mission And so, I think we already got the value out of the spacecraft But the other thing is, even if it's destroyed as it passes through the comet, we expect to get data about halfway through anyway, and that's still going to be very valuable. If all goes as planned, the spacecraft will be in the area of the solar wind between Halley's comet and the sun in early 1986. Intercepting Giacobini-Zinner and studying comet Halley will allow scientists to make comparative studies between the two. Comets are believed to be among the most primitive bodies in space. Scientists believe they can trace the International Cometary Explorer for many years after its cometary encounter. One of the novelties of the orbit that we're in going out to the comet is that the orbital period is kind of synchronized with the Earth's orbital period. And 30 years after we had left the Earth, which is 1983, we'll be coming back close to the Earth again. This is the year 2013. And at that time, we planned on using the moon's gravity once again to recapture the spacecraft and put it into an Earth orbit, and then probably transfer it into a lunar transfer orbit where the spacecraft could be picked up by an advanced shuttle spacecraft. And people can look at it in the Air and Space Museum. It cost less than $5 million dollars to reuse this old spacecraft while it would've required two additional spacecraft at an approximate cost of $100 million each to perform the same job. This has been The Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. space story 1081 four minutes thirty seconds coming in 3 two one one of the areas that stand to benefit most from spaceflight is the ability to make scientific observations of the Earth from space on the next space shuttle mission scheduled for October the orbiter will become an earth observatory and the astronauts will be gathering geologic geographic and oceanographic information about our planet. One of the crew members on this mission is astronaut Kathy Sullivan. Starting off on the very first day of the flight we're going to launch an earth radiation budget satellite that we call ERBS. It's a NASA project that has a variety of scientific instruments aboard that are designed to look at the radiation balance of the earth and hopefully provide some information in concert with other weather satellites that will help us get a better understanding of what drives the world's climates. We have also another set of science experiments that includes a side-looking radar and an imaging experiment to identify features on the ground and an atmospheric pollution experiment. I've been the lead crew member on that group of experiments called OST-3. And all the way in the back of the cargo bay on another rack we'll have a large format camera that will take very high resolution pictures of the Earth's surface on 9 inch by 18 inch frames of film. One of the most interesting experiments on board is the shuttle imaging radar. First flown in the second space shuttle mission, the improved larger radar antenna will obtain data in digital form so it can be run through computers and bring out more subtle detail. About 115 investigators throughout the world are studying the data we will get back with the radar. When we flew an imaging radar on the second shuttle flight, we called it SUR-A, we learned a lot about how stable and how suitable the orbiter is as a platform for an imaging radar. Probably the most startling thing that was discovered on the terrain that Sir A looked at was in the southern portions of Egypt and the eastern areas of Libya. And it was discovered there in some of the great sand seas of the northeastern Sahara that the couple of top meters of sand, six to ten feet or so, were so extremely dry and porous that the radar beams actually could penetrate that layer and would then reflect off of a surface beneath the sand sheet. So what would look to your eye as a just trackless sand sheet if you flew over or were driving across it, to the radar's eye, it turned out to be an old, about 60,000-year-old river system complete with valleys and channels and gravels and sandbars that had just accidentally almost been covered by a sheet of dune sand. This has turned out to tell everybody quite a lot about the earlier climate and the earlier water flow patterns in that region. And archaeologically, it's also turned up a lot of interesting detail about former civilizations in that part of Africa. Some of the very dry areas of Egypt that we looked at with Sir A are again candidates to be looked at with Sir B and see what more detail we might discover with the better equipment. And since we really had never understood before Sur-A that that kind of mapping through the surface was possible, we've looked very carefully on the Sur-B sites for other areas of the world that might be that dry and might have a transparent surface layer beneath which we could see evidence of former rivers or perhaps learn more things about old climates and older civilizations. On this mission, Kathy Sullivan will become the first woman to conduct an extravehicular activity, or spacewalk, Together with crew member Dave Leestma, she will be demonstrating the capability of refueling satellites in space. We asked her what this mission means to her personally. The idea of my being an astronaut came along as I was finishing graduate school and recognized that the kind of expeditionary research that I had enjoyed very much doing at sea and on land as a geologist was also being done in space, and with the advent of the shuttle, there was even a niche, a role in space, for someone with the kind of broad scientific and technical background that I had. I can't fully appreciate sitting here on the ground how amazing and beautiful I expect the Earth to be from that perspective. This has been The Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Space Story 1082 4 minutes 30 seconds coming in 3 2 1 This is the Space Story a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. For many years, astronomers learned about the universe by looking at it in the narrow part of the electromagnetic spectrum called visible light. Later they discovered that stars send out kinds of energy that we cannot see, such as infrared and ultraviolet radiation, radio waves, x-rays, and gamma rays. Each part of the spectrum has its own contributions to make to our understanding of the universe. The Gamma Ray Observatory, scheduled to be launched by the Space Shuttle in 1988, will be a powerful tool for understanding some of the most fascinating objects in space. Pulsars, quasars, active galaxies, and black holes. Dr. Donald Niffen is Project Scientist for the Gamma Ray Observatory at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. Whenever one of these violent events takes place in the universe, a supernova explosion or a black hole or a pulsar, lots of very, very energetic processes take place. And because gamma rays are such high energy, that means in these processes, in these interactions which occur, then a lot of energy is available to go into things like gamma rays. Now, the way that we learn about any object, viewing it through astronomy, You have to deduce what's going on in the vicinity of the place where the gamma rays are being produced by the things that you can see. Gamma rays, like any other photon, travel directly from the source to us so we can make a good guess as to what object they're coming from. But what we want to learn about by observing the gamma rays is what mechanism is occurring. This then tells us about the physics that's going on in the source and hence what sort of types of violent reactions are taking place. And from this then we can learn about things like the evolution of our universe. We can learn about the actual details of the supernova process where very heavy elements are believed to be formed. Dr. David Thompson, also from the Goddard Space Flight Center, explain some of the contributions the Gamma Ray Observatory can make. The observatory will help us understand pulsars. Pulsars were first discovered by radio astronomers, and it is now thought that a pulsar is a rapidly rotating remnant of a star that once lived. When that star died in a supernova explosion, it left behind a tiny core of material, extremely dense material. If you had a sugar cube made out of neutron star material, it would weigh about 300 million tons on the surface of the Earth, a sugar cube. So this is what a neutron star is like. These neutron stars are spinning. And as they spin, they put out pulses of radio emission. And some of these are now known to put out pulses of gamma ray emission. Those that we have studied indicate that even though there are lots more radio waves seen from these, most of the energy that we see coming out of a pulsar is actually in the form of gamma rays. And that means that by studying the gamma rays, we learn something about what it's like around a neutron star, a place that's so exotic and foreign that we can't even picture it on Earth. Quasars also emit tremendous amounts of energy in the form of gamma rays. Quasars have always been considered exotic because they appear to be moving away from us at a large fraction of the speed of light, which may indicate that they are somewhere and they are very distant parts of the universe. And yet the fact that we can see them indicates that they are radiating tremendous amounts of energy and may indeed be powered by black holes. If you want to see what's going on near a black hole, you have to get out something that involves a large amount of energy, and that's a gamma ray. This has been the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Space Story 1,083. 4 minutes 30 seconds. Coming in three, two, one. This is the Space Story. A weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Recent events, such as the 1982 and 83 disastrous El Nino current, which caused billions of dollars in damage and considerable loss of life, have demonstrated the need to better understand the workings of the ocean and its effects on our climate. In the past, satellites have been the key to global measurements of the ocean. One of the instruments on NASA's 1979 CSAT satellite made as many individual measurements of wind speed and direction as were collected during the previous century of shipboard observations. NASA has invited an oceanographer to fly on the next space shuttle mission. Australian-born Paul Scully Power will be performing three major functions during this flight. The first is to test the hypothesis, if you will, that a trained oceanographer up there can see more than an astronaut who's highly trained but not in that particular field. And the second thing is going to be that in recent flights, the astronauts have made some significant new discoveries in oceanography from their flights. For example, they have discovered a new type of ocean eddy which has a spiral structure, most of the ocean eddies that you find in the scientific literature all sort of, the currents are circular. In these new type of eddies were found the currents are in fact spiral. And so there's a recent discovery made by the astronaut crews. And so my second objective is to go look at these new discoveries that they've seen and try and interpret that. And the third major objective is that on this particular flight, it's an Earth Sciences Mission, and specifically they're going to have a synthetic aperture radar looking at the solid Earth and on the oceans. And so I will probably be taking photographs simultaneously with the radar of the ocean sites that the radar is capturing on the radar imaging system. I will be in fact capturing those same sites in colour photography. Both world weather and long term climate changes are strongly linked to ocean behaviour. The weather we've had in the last 18 months has been tied now directly to the North Pacific in terms of anomalous temperature, so it's very obvious and there's a time lag too. The weather patterns that we've seen have been triggered by temperature anomalies in the ocean which occurred six months previously to that. so there's a time lag. So obviously, if you're going to be able to do long-term weather prediction you've got to understand the ocean. And that really makes a lot of sense, and I think everyone's in general agreement with that because if you think of the ocean as a sort of big heat reservoir, it's like a big heat engine that drives the atmosphere. So what happens in the atmosphere is in fact driven by the ocean, and not the other way around. Okay, so therefore oceanography is important. Then in the last two or three years there's been some theoretical work in oceanography that says if you're ever going to understand the ocean dynamics you have to focus on what is called the Mese scale, what that translates to is mid scale and that really is you know events that have size, if you will, of tens to hundreds of miles, okay. For example ocean eddies, and the more we learn about oceanography the more we're finding that there's more and more eddies in the ocean. They have diameters of anywhere say between 70 and 150 miles. So it's right in that mid scale. Now it turns out that from low earth orbit on the shuttle the natural field of view of the human eye or camera system is that scale. So obviously the correct vantage point to see the whole pattern at that scale is from low earth orbit. And so that's one of the rationales as to why I'm due to fly on the shuttle to take advantage of that particular viewing mode. And so you see the connectivity then from what I'm seeing to the mid-sized patterns in the ocean which drives the total ocean dynamics, which drives the atmosphere. And so we can predict the long-term weather prediction. So it really is all tied together. This has been the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. BELL RINGS
